fields.description: Please provide some indication of scalability, such as approximate limits to the number of users that Crowd can support. It would also be useful to include some hardware guidelines to assist users setting up Crowd with their server setup.
fields.summary: Document scalability and hardware requirements

fields.description: When importing data exports that have an application which has no valid groups for authentication, the import will fail with a null pointer.
fields.summary: Data imports fail when no application-group associations are in place.

fields.description: I have paid licenses for jira and confluence and am evaluating crowd.  My evaluation hit a wall this morning when crowd informed me that I maxed out some resource limit for the license.  Need the limit lifted to complete the eval.  Please help!
fields.summary: evaluation license resource limit

fields.description:
I have an Active Directory installation with >1600 groups.  I create a crowd directory for this and then an application definition for jira that uses it.  I added 5 groups from the directory to the crowd application definition.

Over in Jira, however, all 1600 groups show up in the group functions.  Crowd should only return groups to Jira that were associated with the application in its crowd definition.
fields.summary: jira fetches ALL groups from Crowd instead of just those in the crowd group definition for the application

fields.description:
I added 2 groups to a Jira application definition in crowd.  Both groups come from my AD configuration and the authentication flag is set to True.  

Over in Jira, I gave a third group (not one of the two mentioned above) the "jira users" global role.  

A user who is a member of the third group but not one of the first IS allowed to authenticate even though Crowd says that he/she must be a member of one of the crowd-defined groups to get in.
fields.summary: users can authenticate even if not in a group "published" to an application

fields.description: I am working in the console on a named host (myserver.mydomain.com).  The session times out and I get kicked to a localhost URL (server not found).
fields.summary: crowd authentication timeout goes to localhost instead of named host

fields.description:
I have setup a jira -> crowd installation.  In crowd, I have a crowd internal directory and an active directory configuration.  When I try to login as a valid AD user (who belongs to a group that is supposed to have authentication available), crowd does a full scan of the Person objects in my directory.  But it has the samAccountName, so this is meaningless and slow, because it touches thousands of users.

10:58:04,201  INFO crowd.integration.directory.connector.SpringLDAPConnector: Performing principal search: baseDN = OU=PCS,OU=ENT,DC=ent,DC=wfb,DC=bank,DC=corp - filter = (&(objectCategory=Person)(sAMAccountName=*))
fields.summary: crowd scans all Person objects in AD when it doesn't need to.

fields.description:
I have >1600 groups in an AD container.  The View Application->Groups screen makes me use a single drop down to find the group I want and there is no mechanism to filter groups by name.  Since about a thousand of these are distinguished only by 6 digit numbers, this is truly an awful user experience.

I'd much prefer a filterable, searchable list that I can do multiple selections in.
fields.summary: application group editor effectively unusable for large group sets

fields.description: Logging into crowd is currently by the admin account created during setup. Can Crowd be configured to authenticate users against an AD and user gorups within the AD?
fields.summary: Logging into Crowd using Active Directroy Users

fields.description:
We have created a directory in Crowd linking to our AD. 

Viewing groups and users and roles independently works correctly i.e. a list of the appropriate information is displayed

When viewing principles, if you click on the roles tab for the any user returned in your search, the roles tab displays a list of items in which the user name is displayed repeatedly under the Role heading. The attached Bit Map shows the results of selecting the Role tab. The Crowd log is attached.
fields.summary: When viewing roles for users who exist in Active Directory, the roles listed contain the the username & no roles

fields.description:
When configurering crowd for LDAP Active Directory integration, when I try to search for users or groups the system responds with the following error:

Operation failed; nested exception is javax.naming.PartialResultException [Root exception is javax.naming.CommunicationException: planit.local:389 [Root exception is java.net.ConnectException: Connection timed out: connect]]

I've attached the Crowd Log.

I thought that if you have the "Use Node Referrals" option checked this elliminated the above exception.

If I play around with the OU definitions for groups I can at least do a search and returns a list of groups in the specified OU i.e. OU=Planit Security Groups without generating the above exception.

The above OU contains groups and within those groups are users. If I specify the same OU for the Users DN in the tab, it returns now users and doesn't generated the above exception. If I enter one of the subgroups located in the OU=Planit Security Groups to the users DN, it will return all the users listed in this group. This would be OK if all the users are contained in the same groups, but they are split between an ou=Sydney and an ou=Mlebourne where they are listed as" members of" the OU.

Does Crowd perform a recursive search through the tree structure search for the object class = "user" starting from the specified DN which in out case is "OU=PLanit SecurityGroups " as the baseDN = DC=planit,DC=local".


Is there a work around for this or how do I tell Crowd to search the sub tree for user objects. I dfon't want to have to create 2 additional directory connectors just to deal with users located into different OU's. The reason we have split users into geographical locations is that their logins and accounts are managed by their replicated accounts on a local server.


Thank you for your assistance

Regards

Shane Parkinson
fields.summary: Problems with Active Directory Connector and PartialResultException

fields.description:
Currently Crowd offer a (limited) form of application client validation based on the ip address of the application client.
Using the ip address of a client to validate its authenticity is not fail safe. Wouldn't it be a lot better to provide other ways of determining the application client? For example using client side SSL certificates?
fields.summary: Validate a requesting application client based on client SSL certificates

fields.description:
Crowd should allow the definition of proxy servers whose {{X-Forwarded-For:}} it will trust.

Original customer description:
{quote}Our company policy is to run our Tomcat containers behind a Apache proxy. This proxy then forwards the requests to the Tomcat servers. In the case of Crowd it leads to an undesired situation. Crowd thinks the application authentication request comes from 127.0.0.1 instead of the external ip address of the application.
In Crowd therefore I cannot  validate an application on it's ip address. Which might result in security hazards.
Is their another way to determine the original client ip-address instead of the proxy's ip-address?{quote}
fields.summary: Allow specification of Trusted Proxy Servers

fields.description:
There is a mistake in section 2.2.5 of the Crowd install documentation guide. In part 3, "Configure your application server to connect to PostgreSQL", under part one says "Edit the conf/Catalina/localhost/crowd.xml and customise the username, password, driverClassName and url parameters for the Datasource." is should say, "Edit the conf/Catalina/localhost/{color:red} *openidserver.xml*{color} and customise the username, password, driverClassName and url parameters for the Datasource."

URL: http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/CROWD/2.2.5+PostgreSQL
fields.summary: CrowdID Install Documentation Mistake

fields.description:
When I downloaded Crowd I noticed that it comes prewired for tomcat.  Is
it possible to get the Crowd war file so that we may deploy to jboss or
is the recommended action to create a war from the files included in the
crowd download?
fields.summary: Need and EAR/WAR download to use other application servers

fields.description:
I would like to have an audit trail in crowd, showing the administrative actions that were done. This would give you a clear view of what has been changed recently in crowd. Now there is no way of knowing what the crowd administrators have changed.

*Update:* As of Crowd 3.2 it is possible to track the following administrative actions via a built-in audit log:
* All user group and membership changes happening in any of your directories
* Changes to the system configuration of Crowd
* Adding or removing applications, updating application configuration
* Adding or removing directories, updating directory configuration

More info in: https://confluence.atlassian.com/crowd/crowd-3-2-release-notes-949250099.html

For those interested in tracking user/group/membership changes, please refer to CWD-3298
fields.summary: Provide audit logs for administrative actions in Crowd
Method to create a token for a principal without performing an authentication.

fields.description: Populate Crowd with 50,000 users and integrate JIRA --- then report back on problems and come up with solutions!
fields.summary: JIRA performance improvements

fields.description:
Crowd 1.2 needs to be upgraded to Spring Framework 2.0.6 from 1.2.x so that Crowd dependencies on Atlassian components can be upgraded.

The Atlassian components have been upgraded to Spring 2.0 for Confluence 2.7 and Bamboo 2.0 release targets.

When this work commences Crowd needs to take upgrades to all Atlassian components and the dependency tree analyzed by the Release Engineer.
fields.summary: Upgrade Crowd to Spring Framework 2.0.6 from 1.2.x

fields.description: The crowd documentation does not explain how to use roles in crowd. I see the tab for create roles in the crowd console and can add a role to a principal. But it is not clear to me how the do something useful with roles in Crowd.
fields.summary: Document the use of roles in Crowd

fields.description:
I'm using CROWD and SSO for being able to log in in several applications such as Jira, Confluence and my own web application. My own web application provides a simplified user interface for searching Confluence pages and creating Jira issues. The connection web application in integrated into Jira and Confluence using their SOAP interfaces. SOAP integration is done with axis.

Now, I'm trying to get the whole set operated. I though that I could use the token received form CROWD (HttpAuthenticator.getToken()) and pass it as a parameter to the methods in the SOAP interfaces of Jira and Confluence. However, when I try to use that I get these kind of answers:

Jira: 
org.springframework.remoting.RemoteAccessException: Cannot access remote service [{http://spoink.solita.fi:8081/rpc/soap/jirasoapservice-v2}jirasoapservice-v2]; nested exception is com.atlassian.jira.rpc.exception.RemoteAuthenticationException: User not authenticated yet, or session timed out.

Confluence:
org.springframework.remoting.RemoteAccessException: Cannot access remote service [{http://spoink.solita.fi:8082/rpc/soap-axis/confluenceservice-v1}confluenceservice-v1]; nested exception is com.atlassian.confluence.rpc.InvalidSessionException: User not authenticated or session expired. Call login() to open a new session

I tried to pass also a "foo" String as token. I got similar responses, meaning that I cannot be sure if this CROWD token is not meant for this kind of functionality at all.

My question is how could I utilize the SSO authentication in Jira /Confluence integration. I'm not willing to create an additional login page into my web application just for being able to get user's password. The password as a "real" text is needed for making login via in Jira / Confluence SOAP interface.
fields.summary: CROWD token and Jira / Confluence SOAP integration

fields.description: I realize that Crowd doesn't support DB2. However, we are a DB2 shop and having purchased licenses for Confluence and are going to purchase licenses for  JIRA. It would be nice if Crowd supported DB2. Both Jira and Confluence support DB2, why not Crowd?
fields.summary: DB2 Support

fields.description:
Some work has been done in the [Confluence Extension space|http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/CONFEXT/Siteminder+custom+Seraph+authenticator+for+Confluence] around adding support for Siteminder for Confluence. This has been by extending Confluence's authenticator.

A 'nicer' approach would be to use Crowd (removing the need to create a user in Confluence).

Some information is needed in just how Siteminder stores/access it's "users" and how it handles credentials and SSO.
fields.summary: Extend Crowd's Seraph Authenticator to provide support for Siteminder.

fields.description:
We have created a group in Crowd for developers who need to access Bamboo.
Adding a Principal in Crowd to that group has no effect in Bamboo
The Group Browser in Bamboo does no reflect the real situation in Crowd and shows the number of members to the group before adding new principals.

Because these principals also can not login to Bamboo we consider this as a blocking issue..
Rebooting Bamboo causes an update of its knowledges about the groups and allows our users to login

fields.description:
The atlassian-user framework uses diplayName to represent the full name of a principal, ie. user creations / updates to full name will propogate through as displayName changes in Crowd.

The JiveForums integration uses a concatenation of firstName and surname attributes to form the full name.

This currently causes conflicts when a user is created via Confluence for example, and then retrieved via Jive.

The behaviour should be similar to what is implemented in the Crowd Console:
# Searching for full name: if displayName attribute exists, use it; otherwise concatenate firstName and surname attributes and return it.
# Adding/updating full name: update both displayName and firstName/surname attributes.
fields.summary: Full Name attribute (displayName/firstName+surname) used differently by atlassian-user and JiveForums

fields.description:
When CWD-314 was implemented we were able to meet the current functionality for JIRA & Confluence integration by having Crowd's JIRA integration (via Seraph) use the credentials present in the URL to be used for that given request; when grabbing RSS feeds from JIRA.

To take this one step further we should now use the authenticated 'browser user' and not the credentials present in the request to authenticate the user; however we may need to keep backwards compatibility here by allowing both.

Currently the Confluence jiraissue macro makes its request on the server side to JIRA, this means that Confluence is making the request to JIRA and not the browser, so any credentials present in the browser session are not used by Confluence for the request. We have two options (from what I can see to implement this feature):
# Provide a configuration item to the jiraportlet marco to tell it to grab the Crowd authentication token from the users session (cookie) and use that (assuming that we are on the same domain).
# Re-write the plugin as an 'ajax-based' macro so the browser makes the request and not Confluence, this would then simply use the currently authenticated Confluence user for the request on JIRA.
fields.summary: The Confluence JIRA Issue macro currently uses the hard coded os_username and os_password properties for authentication, it would be nice to use the authenticated user in the browser.

My company currently has licensed versions of JIRA and Confluence.  We are using the EAR/WAR packages and have them installed in our Tomcat server environment.

We are currently evaluating Crowd, but it is only offered as a standalone version.  While could maintain multiple Tomcat instances, we would rather not do this.  It is also inconvenient to have to take apart the Crowd standalone and create our own EAR/WAR package.

Please strongly consider offering a EAR/WAR package for Crowd in a future release.

Thank you.

It turns out that LDAP error 532 means that the users password is expired.  I would like to see the Crowd API handle these sort of exceptions better and, where possible, pass these errors back to the client so that they can be displayed to the user.   Telling the user their password is expired at the login page instead of printing a bunch of unintelligible stack traces just seems like a much better UI experience.
{quote}

fields.description:
Currently Crowd login session tokens are stored in the primary DB (in our case postgres).  However the usage patterns of the updates and deletes on these do not suit an ACID database, and frequent reindexes are required to stop perfomance degradation.  Over time this can cause long delays during authentication.   More information [here|http://www.postgresql.org/docs/8.1/static/routine-reindex.html].

As this is volatile data it would be better stored in a Crowd-local cache, preferably disk-backed.  This would improve overall performance both for authentication and for other DB apps.
fields.summary: Storing login tokens in an external DB is inefficient

fields.description:
I'm trying to integrate Crowd with Jira and Confluence through SOAP using PHP client.
I've written a SOAP client using PHP and successfully call to several methods, such as:
authenticateApplication, authenticatePrincipal, invalidateToken, addPrincipal, addPrincipalToGroup.

With authenticatePrincipal, the php code received the user token. I've also checked from the console
that there is a valid session for the user. However, when I try to go to Jira or Confluence, that user is
not log-on.

However, if I login from Jira or Confluence, I can go to the other application just fine. I made sure as well
the Application have jira-users and confluence-users added to the Group.
fields.summary: After receiving token from authenticatePrincipal SOAP, JIRA/Confluence are still not "login"

Proposed Solution:
The Problem I found that after authentication request is processed by the crowd server, the Http response object returned in response contains information 
about the token "crowd.token_key" not the http request object. Therefore  the api to access the authentication token using  request object is failing. Crowd must introduce another api with HttpAuthenticator to retrieve authentication token from response object
fields.summary: HttpAuthenticator getToken api does not return the Principal for the Authenticated User

fields.description:
The core Crowd jar seems to have much more in it than is required to integrate a client. In particular, the hibernate mapping file at the root of the jar (which is unnecessary in making a client) gets picked up by Grails when included in a Grails project and Grails tries to create Hibernate domain objects for the listed mappings. Removing the hibernate mapping file from the jar works, but I think it would be nice to have a seperate, slimmed down Crowd-client.jar which only has what is required to get a client running.

More work, I know, but it would be nice...

Also, requirements for client integration are sparse, but that is addressed elsewhere.
fields.summary: Crowd core jar breaks in Grails, need a new slimmed-down client jar

fields.description:
Currently, integrating Crowd with JIRA requires the enabling of "External User Management".

This means that JIRA cannot modify users in Crowd. It would be nice to allow Crowd user management via JIRA like Confluence/Bamboo.
fields.summary: JIRA user management should allow admins to update Crowd users

fields.description:
The build script to set the server ports and the like copies across the "standard" crowd.properties, overwrites the existing one and modifies the values.

This will cause the old password to be lost and thus reset to "password".

Current workaround is to backup crowd.properties and transfer the password into the crowd.properties generated by the script.
fields.summary: Build script overwrites old password

fields.description:
Remote application's calls to removePrincipal(name) only removes the first principal it finds in the applications associated directories.

It should remove all principals in the applications associated directories.

Also removing a group or role from a principal should remove the group or role from all principals across the applications assigned directories.
fields.summary: Remote application's calls to removePrincipal(name) only removes the first principal it finds

fields.description:
Remote application's calls to removeRole(name) only removes the first role it finds in the applications associated directories.

It should remove all roles in the applications associated directories.
fields.summary: Remote application's calls to removeRole(name) only removes the first role it finds

fields.description:
Remote application's calls to removeGroup(name) only removes the first group it finds in the applications associated directories.

It should remove all groups in the applications associated directories.
fields.summary: Remote application's calls to removeGroup(name) only removes the first group it finds

fields.description: The aggregated members from the data access layer does not correspond to the actual group-memberships for those users. Thus finding a group by a name may return the correct group but the members array of the group may not actually belong to the group.
fields.summary: Internal Directory search for Group by name is failing to aggregate the correct members

fields.description:
A group must be defined in a directory. However, groups across multiple directories (ie. groups with the same name in different directories) should be treated as one single logical group.

The SOAP object graph defines a SOAPGroup as a subclass of SOAPEntity. A SOAPEntity has a directoryID. In order to decouple the logical group, this directoryID should be removed from the SOAPGroup. A rethinking of the SOAP objects is required as this change will affect the object hierarchy.
fields.summary: Decouple Groups from Directories

fields.description: It would be nice to be able to save the "Results Per Page" setting. In any case, having it at 10 is way too low for any real-life application and forces me to reload the page everytime I used it. I'd like to be able to save this in the profile.
fields.summary: Save Results Per Page settings

fields.description: It would be nice to be able to view all the members of a group (in the group view) or a role (in  the role view)
fields.summary: View members of the group or role
